REPORT OF THE AUDITOR OF PUBLIG AGGOUNTS.
The State of Nebraska
Office of Auditor of Public Accounts
Lincoln, December 1, 1904.
To His Excellency, John II. Mickey, Governor of the State of Nebraska :
Dear Sir: I have the honor to submit herewith the biennial report of this department of the state government for the two years ending November 30, 1904, in compliance with section IS, article 5 of the Constitution, and section 3, article 3, chaptt Compiled Statutes of 1903.
The accompanying tabular statements are believed to be comprehensive and full with reference to the fiscal transactions of the state government; and they present much other information of public importance not specifically called for by said section 3, article 3, chapter 83, Compiled Statutes of 1903. Statement No. 1 shows the amount of each fund in the State Treasury December 1, 1902, all receipts and disbursements to and including November 30, 1904, and the balances for each fund remaining in the State Treasury December 1, 1904. Statement No. 2 shows Treasury receipts and disbursements in greater detail. rment No. 3 gives a full and detailed statement of the public and shows fully all liabilities and resources of the state. Statements Nos. 4 and 5 give estimates of the revenue and expenditures for the biennial period commencing April 1, 1905 and ending April 1, 1907. Revenue estimates are based upon the assessment and levy for 1904; but in making up the estimates only eighty-five per cent of the levy of 1904 was incorporated, allowing fifteen per cent for delinquent and uncollectible taxes.

6
To the probable income from the levy were added estimates of the probable income from all miscellaneous sources, such estimates being based on the actual receipts for the fiscal year ending November 30, 1904. Estimates of expenditures for the forthcoming biennial period as shown in statements No. 5. are largely based upon data furnished by heads of departments and institutions. Statement No. t>A shows separately the whole amount of each appropriation of money made by the twenty-eighth session of the legislature, the amount paid under the same and the balance unexpended November 30, 1904. Statements 7 to 8B inclusive show in detail taxes paid by counties during the biennium ending November 30, 1904 and the taxes still due from counties. Statements Nos. 22 and 23 contain the grand assessment rolls for the years 1903 and 1904 respectively, and show the amount and value of all classes of taxable property returned by the several county assessors to the state board of equalization. Besides the foregoing statements to which attention has been particularly called there are many others of importance, such as the statements showing the investment of the permanent school fund, the levy of state taxes for the years 1903 and 1904, and the railroad assessment for the years 1903 and 1904.
At the close of the biennium November 30, 1902, the floating interest bearing debt of the state amounted to $1,989,328.63. At the close of the biennium November 30, 1904 this floating interest bearing debt amounted to $2,253,386.40, showing an increase of $264,057.77 for the biennium. These figures relate exclusively to the general fund. The increase noted was the inevitable result of large appropriations and limited revenues. The general fund appropriations made by the twenty-eighth session of the legislature amounted to $2,855,343.70, an amount greatly in excess of general fund appropriations made for any preceding biennium. The increase in appropriations was largely due to unusual amounts appropriated for permanent improvements. During the biennium for which these appropriations were made there was no possible corresponding increase in revenues. Expenditures under these appropriations had to be met largely by receipts from the levies of 1902 and 1903; that is to say

.
by receipts from levies made on the low valuations returned under the old revenue law. The total assessment for 1902 was $179,976,567.81 and the average levy was only H ™ il18 - The total assessment for 1903 was $188,458,379.44 and the average levy was 5 9-10 mills. The receipts from these levies together with receipts from the delinquent tax list and from all miscellaneous sources have not been sufficient to meet the extraordinary appropriations made by the legislature of 1903. Those appro priations were based on estimates of the probable income under the new revenue law, but as demonstrated above the only revenues available to meet them have been the revenues derived from levies and collections under the old revenue law. It seems
probable that there will be a still further increase in the floating debt, but this increase will soon be overtaken by receipts from the first levy made under the new revenue law; and the amount outstanding November 30, 1904 should practically mark the extreme limit of high tide in the floating debt of the state It should be observed in this connection that the increase of the floating debt during the past biennium is in no way due to a failure on the part of the new revenue law to respond to the purposes for which it was framed. The first levy under the new law was not made until July 1904. Personal property taxes did not become delinquent until December 1, 1904 and real property taxes do not become delinquent until May 1. 1905. Consequently, very little if any revenue was received by the state under and by virtue of the new revenue law prior to November 30, 1904. The increase of the floating debt up to the present time has been wholly due to inadequate revenues under the old law.
In addition to the general fund indebtedness above|designated the Temporary University Fund for the first time in years showed a deficit of $75,488.78 November 30, 1904, warrants to that amount having been issued in excess of funds on hand. Univer sity appropriations were based on estimates of probable income under the new revenue law. Under and by virtue of these appropriations, large expenditures have been made by the Board of Regents during the past year for permanent improvements such as the new physics building on the campus and the new building

8
Pm. These large expenditures coming in balk and withf period necessarily anticipated the revenues for the to some extent. Most of the contemplated permanent lents are approaching completion and the receipts of the temporary fund should soon begin to rapidly outrun expenditures. It is safe to predict that within a few months the deficit will be wiped out and the fund again placed on a cash basis.
As shown by statement No. 4 the total estimated income of the general fund for the fiscal period commencing April 1, 1905 and ending March 31, 1907 is $2,819,244.71. This estimate, of course, is based largely on the probable income from the levies of 1905 and 1906, it being presumed that the assessments and the levies for those years will not differ widely from the total assessment and levy for the year 1904. The total assessment for the year 1904 amounts to $294,779,244.65, and the levy was 4£ mills, being within one-half mill of the limit. Under the law as it stands at present there cannot be another valuation of real property for three years and in any event the levy cannot be increased more than half a mill over the levy of 1904. Conse quently, it seems reasonable to assume that the income from the levy for each of the years 1905 and 1906 will not greatly exceed the estimated income from the levy of 1904. To the estimated income from the levies of 1905 and 1906 have been added a conservative estimate of income from back taxes and a very considerable amount derivable from miscellaneous sources as shown by statement No. 4, making the total estimate of income for the general fund $2,819,244.71 as stated above.
As against this estimated general fund income of 2,819,244.-71, the estimated requirements for the biennial period commencing April 1, 1905 and chargeable to the general fund amount to $2,540,316.00. These estimates are set forth in statement No. 5. Estimates in greater detail have been prepared by the heads of departments and institutions and are on file in this office and subject to inspection. The appropriations for 1903 included unusual sums for permanent improvements. In making up the estimates for the forthcoming biennium appropriations for permanent improvements have been eliminated almost entire! v.

9
REPORT OF THE AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS.
Nearly all of the estimates for maintenance, repairs, etc., are in excess of the appropriations made for the current biennium. The most notable increase is found in the estimates for the National Guard, the Hastings Asylum, the Soldiers' Home at Grand Island, the Lincoln Aejlum, the Peru Normal School and the Milford Industrial Home. The Milford Industrial Home, the Girls' Industrial School at Geneva and the Lincoln Home for the Friendless are expensive institutions. The per capita cost of maintenance in these institutions seems extravagant when compared with other institutions. This condition, however, does not indicate that there has been mismanagement or extravagant expenditures. It arises from the fact that these institutions are maintained for the accommodation of a comparatively limited number of inmates in each institution; and it illustrates the economical mistake involved in the policy of maintaining several institutions of a similar character when one could have been made
to answer the purpose. On the whole it does not seem probable that the estimates in question can be greatly scaled down without impairing the present dosirable standard of excellence and efficiency in the administration of state institutions.
I\. comparison of the estimates of income and expenditure for biennial period commencing April 1, 1905, indicates a probe surplus of receipts over expenditures amounting in round iibers tt> $280,000.00, this result being based, of course, upon assumption that legislative appropriations will not exceed the egoing estimate. Moreover, this eetimaU of surplus is based a levy of 4£ mills. If the levy is increased to the l^gal limit five mills the surplus available for the reduction o 4 the floating it during the biennium ought to exceed §500,000.00.
The Board of Regents asks for appropriations for the State University amounting to $842,170.00. This estimate includes an item or" $32,000.00 for the maintenance of farmers' institutes and the experimental substation at North Platte. The Regents ask that this amount be appropriated from the state general fund. The request seems reasonable. While the maintenance of farmers' institutes and the experimental substation at North Platte is placed under the control >f the Board of Regents, it is not a

10
part of the University work proper and should not be a burden on University funds. With this item deducted the total appropriation asked from University funds is $810,470.00, this amount being the estimated income of the various University funds during the biennium ending March 31, 1907. The estimated in come for the temporary fund from the one mill levy is 559,970.-00. Th-! balance of the estimated aggregate income, amounting to $270,500.00, is derived as follows: United States Morrill fund $50,000.00; United States Experiment Station fund $30,000,00; University Caeh fund from students and other cash sources $100,000.00; from the land grant fund aud miscellaneous sources $90,500.00. While University estimates seem large, the fact should be held in mind that only about 67 per cent of the estimate comes from the tax levy. A detailed estimate of the needs of the University is on file in this office. The biennial report of the Board of Regents will discuss the finances of the University in still greater detail. Theestimates for permanent improvements amount to $137,470.00. These proposed permanent improvements consist largely of buildings on the farm and equipment for the school of agriculture. In view of the growing attendance in the school of agriculture and the increasing necessity for intelligent equipment on the part of those who engage in agricultural pursuits, liberal appropriations may well be made without incurring a just charge of extravagance. Indeed, the name plea may be made for all departments of University work. The appropriations seem large but the University iD many respects is the largest and most important public enterprise in the state; and io board having in charge the expenditure or' public funds is more continually and effectually controlled by considerations of economy than the Board of Regents of the State University.
A few words have been said above in regard to the results that may be reasonably anticipated from the new revenue law. The first assessment under the new law furnishes abundant ground for belief that the measure is in the main a wise one. It has not been • disappointment because it has largely accomplished the purposes or which it was framed. The evils that crew up under the old

11
law were chiefly those of inequality, undervaluation and evasion of taxation. These evils have been largely removed and further experience in the administration of the law will undoubtedly reduce them to a minimum. The inequalities that prevailed under the old law were a constant source of embarrassment to the State Board of Equalization. So great were these inequalities that it was impossible for the board both to equalize assessments and raise sufficient revenue to meet the current expenditures of the state. The assessment of 1904 shows a vast improvement in this respect. Some inequalities existed in the assessments as returned by the county assessors, but the task of equalization was comparatively easy. The state board changed the assessment in only twenty-four out of the ninety counties; and in no county did the change amount to more than ten per cent of the assessment as returned by the county assessor. Under the old law the differ ences sometimes amounted to more than sixty percent of the returned valuation. The evil of undervaluation has been greatly reduced under the new law. There is evidently an opportunity for further improvement in this respect, but the gain has been so great that the result may be considered a substantial success on the part of the new law. An inspection of the grand assessment roll for 1904 and a comparison of the same with the assessment of 1903, will disclose the fact that the new law has succeeded in
placing upon the tax books many millions in value of personal property not hitherto assessed. Space does not permit a referencelo these items in detail. Something remains to be accomplished in this resptct also, but the gain has been sufficient to justify the anticipations of the framers of the law.
Some desirable amendments to the law may be briefly noted. The term "credits" is not clearly defined. The Attorney General has rendered an opinion to the effect that the term at used in the revenue law meant net ertditt and in this opinion he seems to be supported by the ruling of the Supreme court. The court, however, has not passed upon the question directly and conclu sively. In any event, the question is an important one and should be settled by legislative enactment rather than by judicial decision. Assessors in some of the countie*s have rejected the

12
.
Attorney General's opinion as well as the application of that opinion made by the state board, and as a result there has been no uniformity in the assessment of credits, thereby creating much dissatisfaction in the public mind.
The inability of the board to equalize as between counties by simply adding to or deducting from the valuation of those classes of property that are too low or too high as the case may be has also been the cause of much discussion and dissatisfaction. In some cases the board was obliged to raise valuations where the low valuations seemed to be due entirely to the undervaluation of certain classes of property. When the board increased the valuation in a case of this kind, the increase applied to property properly valued as well as to the property undervalued. The law offered no alternative. It seems to be beyond dispute that * change in the law enabling the state board to equalize by increas ing or decreasing valuations of classes of property improperly assessed, without affecting all property assessed, would lead to a more equitable and satisfactory assessment.
Section 136 of the revenue law requires that county boards shall on the last day of their sitting as a board of equalization levy the necessary taxes for the current year. Section 132 provides that the final equalization by the state board shall be taken as the final assessment for all purposes, both stale and local. The equalization of the state board cannot be completed, or ¦ entered upon, until after the adjournment of county boards as boards of equalization. Consequently, county boards are required by law to make their levy before the assessment upon which bucIi levy is to be made has been made final and complete by the State Board of Equalization. The county boards should be authorized by law to convene and make the necessary levy after the tessment has been completed and certified to the county clerks the State Board of Equalization. It has been suggested that the assessment as it loaves the hands of the county board of equalization be taken, as the final assessment for all local purposes and that the work of the state board of equalization be limited to equalization for state purposes. The great danger of

13
I ited under the old revenue iaw. Greater uniformity of asseMlt will be secured when local and county assessor* and county rds of equalization realize that the entire assessment for all poses will be subject to inspection and revision by a central rd whose jurisdiction covers all the counties in the state.
Delinquent taxes November 30, 1908, amounted to 1,141,-#00.M. At the close of the fiscal year November 30, 1904, delinquent taxes amounted to $1, 153,551.11. This estimate elusive of all taxes due under the levy of 1004. A verv large per cent of the delinquent tax is for years prior to 1902 and extending as far back as 1859. It is safe to assume that only a small per cent of the delinquent tax for years prior to l'.*o-2 will ever be collected. An inspection of Statements 7 and 7A will disclose the small amount of taxes collected during the pa*t biennium for years prior to 1902. No great amount of revenue will ever be realized from the delinquent tax list. Income from future levies must be depended upon for the reduction and final disposal of the floating debt of the state.
Reference has been made to the fact that tax cha I i nst various counties extend as far as 18S9. These balances are brought forward from year to year. While it in a matter of absoluti tainty that they will never be paid in full, or even in part in some instances, the law provides no method and no authority for closing the accounts. The provisions of law for settlements with counties are incomplete and unsatisfactory. The law pro that where real property is sold for an amount less than the acfumulated taxes the proceeds shall be prorated in the payment af state, county and city general taxes. The law does not provide that in such cases, the counties shall have credit on the books of the state for the unpaid balances. This simply helps to swell the uncollectible balances charged to the counties and brought forward from year to year. Again, a number of claims are pending between the state and certain counties for money lost in insolvent banks. These claims are all of several years standing. The affairs of the banks have been closed up, and the connfies demand credit for the full amount of state money placed in such banks. State officials have no authoritv to make settlements in

14
such cases. The liability of counties in such cases has not bepn fully determined. The subject must remain one of control between the auditing department and a number of counties uutil the questions involved are settled by judicial decision or by legislative enactment. The books of the state are still encumbered with charges against numerous counties for the maintenance of the insane, made under and by virtue of section 47, chapter 40, Compiled Statutes of 1903, and amounting to $112,047.37. These charges are all at least of ten years standing. During the past biennium, an effort has been made by this department to close up these accounts with all the counties. Some collections have been made and in some instances counties have made levies as required by law for the purpose of discharging these obligations. Most of the counties, however, have failed to respond in any manner to notices and requests from this department, and in such cases, the accounts remain without any prospect of immediate adjustment.
Inheritance tax collections now amount to §5673.60. These ections are carried by the State Treasurer as an inheritance fund, and are not subject to use or expenditure for any pnre. The legislature should provide for the placing of present amulations as well as all future collections to the credit of the eral fund. Chapter 100, Session Laws of 1903, provides that moneys earned by convict labor shall be deposited with the te Treasurer and turned into the general fund. When this went into effect the balance to the credit of tbe Penitentiary or fund amounted to §1588.80. The State Treasurer is still rying this amount as a penitentiary special labor fund, and it lot subject to use or expenditure. It should be carried to the eral fund by legislative enactment.
A summary of the insurance business of the state for the past biennium ig incorporated herewith and made a part of this report. Mr. John L. Pierce, Insurance Deputy, in his letter of trausmittal, which is made a part of the insurance teport, furnishes a statement of the receipts incident to the business of the department during the biennium, and makes certain recommendations with reference to needed insurance legislation that are worth v of attention.
Respectfully submitted
Chakles Wkston.
Auditor of I 'nl, I unis.

KThe law governing nt. Sickness. Funeral Benefit Insu i the nt Han" found i )T to Ki4. ch. 4.1 Com utesof Nebraska to 1 1903, should be amended in -
tlst. Hm title la broader than the a<;t, in than it ilation and control of sucli corporations organized in other - doing business in this state, whereas Hm law itself is silent admission of companies troni other st it
2nd. There is no provision in this law for the riling of the articles

310
of incorporation in the office of the Auditor of Public- Accounts. As such requirement is made of other classes of insurance companies, it is proper i hat a similar requirement should be made of this claas of comp nies.
3rd. This law is silent also as to fees, and should be amended so as to include license fees and fees for admission and examination of articles of incorporation and by-laws, also fees for filing annual statement.
4th. Sec. 155 of this law requires the Auditor of Slate to publish the annuil statements of said companies in detail in his annual report. The law should be amended requiring the publication only of a summary of the annual statement, in order to be in harmony with the laws governing oilier companies, as in their case merely * summary is required.
1 would recommend the enactment of a law which would prohibit discrimination by life insurance companies in favor of individuals of the same class and of the same expectation of life either in the amount of premium charged or in return of premiums, dividends or other advantages.
I would also recommend the enactment of a new law governing fraternal beneficiary societies, as the present law is inadequate in many particulars. It is also desirable that the law governing fraternal beneficiary societies should be as near uniform as possible with the laws of other states governing such societies.
Following will be found a list of companies admitted to and withdrawn from the State, also statements of risks written, premiums received, losses paid, etc.
